This is one thing that is not as crazy as it sounds China Uncensored 
especially where the environment is concerned.

Commercial jets will always beat trains in terms of travel-time, and 
potential destinations. But, they have disadvantages. 1) They are seriously 
polluting sons-of-bitches. 2) And when hauling cargo, there's serious 
limits to carrying capacity, and the closer you get to hitting those limits 
the less fuel efficient and less safe the aircraft becomes. Which is why 
airlines feel obliged to charge people for their extra-baggage. 3) We are 
no where near producing an alternative clean fuel solution for aircraft 
that will allow their travel-time advantage. So, jets will likely always be 
fossil-fuel guzzlers in ways that trains simply aren't. And in ways future 
sea-freighters don't have to be, and likely won't be.   

Trains/Rail beat jets in terms of potential cargo capacity, carbon emission 
friendliness, and fuel efficiency costs. If the world ever does agree on 
environmental carbon emissions caps, it would effectively cap the fleet 
size of various national airlines across the globe, but the rail industry 
would be incentivized by higher passenger demand, and the skyrocketing 
costs of the airline industry.  

Rail transport also beats sea-freight depending upon the root. (it's hard 
to compete with a ready made near zero-maintenance travel medium in terms 
of direct routes, but for very indirect routes there are no real 
advantages.)
 
For instance, the China to Europe rail route would cut the distance 
traveled between them in half. It's hard to say if the Chinese American 
route would have similar advantages. However, with the rising waters of 
current climate change projections, the major sea-ports of the world in the 
later half of this century are likely facing some serious engineering 
upgrades to piers, docks, locks, and dikes, and other things of that nature 
which will add to their costs.

Passenger travel has been the primary driving force in commercial aviation, 
and incidental to rail-work. Most cargo craft are just conversions of 
passenger aircraft to allow for more cargo, but the maximum takeoff weight 
limit of each aircraft is fixed and includes the fuel weight (which is a 
lot of the aircrafts actual weight at take off.) So, the real benefit of 
laying down tracks anywhere is cargo. Passengers who prefer to ride on 
them, or can't afford to fly, is just a bonus to the real reason 
governments and companies lay down tracks.﻿

Here, let's put it this way. Japan's Shinkansen high speed railway network 
is the oldest high speed rail network with 50 years of milage without a 
single person who lost their lives on the tracks. It also holds a record of 
being very accurate, with only a few second delay for every train 
(excluding naturally caused delays). On the other hand, China's High speed 
railway is almost the newest, but has caused a fatal accident, and buried 
it, trying to hide the evidence. 

Also, I find the China-US and England-China rail lines pointless. Put it 
this way- it is going to cost a fortune to create these lines, and it is 
doubtful that people are going to use it. This means the tickets are going 
to be very expensive, and it may be more expensive compared to air tickets. 
Also, the electrification would cost a lot to manage. To add more, They 
need to think of how they are going to deal with the sand on the 
England-China line and the snow and freezing temperatures on the China-US 
line.

Lastly, safety. What if a train gets breaks down in the middle of a desert 
or in a thick wooded forest of siberia? How would the people be saved? Is 
their going to be emergency rations on the train? I doubt it, based on the 
accident. 

In short, I believe that safety come before anything, and the days of a 
global high-speed rail is impossible with current skills and safety 
features of China's High-speed rail.  ﻿

Well if you actually knew anything about the US you would realize we are 
big into using trains to haul freight instead of passengers.  You can look 
up and compare how much freight the US moves compared to Europe and it is 
rather ridiculous how much the US moves freight by train then Europe does.  
Roughly 75% of all new automobiles are moved across country using trains.  
More freight is going onto domestic 53 ft. containers and getting 
transported across the country by train...in fact it might be better to say 
NAFTA containers since Canada and Mexico are starting to get in the deal as 
well. 

The reason why so many people in Europe travel by train compared to the 
United States is because Europe choose to focus on passenger rail.  In the 
US it's the opposite with us focusing on moving freight by train.  As far 
as which is more beneficial to focus on that would be moving freight by 
train.  Since it cuts down on pollution from commercial trucks by not 
having as many on the road.  It also cuts down on maintenance costs on our 
highways.  Not to mention moving freight by train makes a much bigger 
profit then passenger rail service. 

As far as why the US doesn't have ultra large passenger rail service 
everywhere in the country that's due to several factors.  One being the 
rise of the automobile in the US and then the creation of the interstate 
highway system and commercial passenger flights also being another.  For a 
long time in the US passenger rail service was offered by the rail 
companies because they were forced to offer it by the US government.  
Usually they lost money offering passenger rail service the same way Amtrak 
in the United States still loses money because it services a lot of remote 
areas.  The reason why the rail roads like Norfolk Southern, CSX, Union 
Pacific, etc stopped passenger rail service is because after the US 
government created Amtrak they no longer forced rail roads to offer 
passenger rail service. 

Most of the rail roads in the US went bust until the rail roads were 
allowed to deregulate because until they were allowed to do so they were 
constantly losing business to the US trucking industry.  It took 
deregulation and a few decades of BS for the rail roads to recover from all 
that.  Now they have become very profitable with North American intermodal 
transport and the shale boom.  They have become so profitable Warren Buffet 
used his fortune to buy Union Pacific rail road. 

So to answer your question of why people in the US don't use passenger rail 
and why the service is what it is in the United States it's not hard to see 
why if you actually knew anything about how transportation in this nation 
came to be what it is.  Of course you being absolutely clueless about how 
transportation truly is in the United States just spouted off some bullshit 
and just made yourself look like an even bigger ass then you have before.

+runthemhot250 Sorry for the long comment, if you want, the first sentences 
of each paragraph should be enough info.

*Aeroplanes cause quite a lot of pollution, actually.* Even when you just 
look at it as 'measure of pollution (emission) per person per distance 
(constant) travelled. An aeroplane is required to fly at high speeds, that 
requires a large force to go against that of the force of gravity (working 
between the plane and earth, thus being proportional to the 'amount' of 
passengers) and the frictional force caused by air. At high speeds such as 
required for planes this force is significantly high, especially because it 
has a relatively low efficiency.

Now trains do vary. Trains that directly emit carbon-dioxide still pollute 
less than a plane. Though the air is denser closer to the ground, most 
trains can be shaped in such a way that it still undergoes less frictional 
force than planes, that does include the frictional force caused by the 
surface. It also doesn't have to worry about gravitational force, that 
force is included in the frictional force caused by the surface and is 
otherwise outdone by the normal force. 

Then you have trains that work on electricity. This can have variable 
emission, all depending on the source. If the source is a power plant that 
burns fossil fuels, it'll have a relatively equal amount of emission as 
other trains. But if it's generated by something renewable such as solar 
power, wind power, it's pollution is (near) zero. ﻿

I live in China and use the high speed rail network all the time. It is 
fast, convenient, modern and cheap to use.  

For example, a flight from Shanghai to Beijing takes roughly 2 hours and 
you need to arrive at the airport 2 hours early, then pick up your bags 
after. In addition, you would need to get yourself into the Beijing city 
center after landing.  For the same cost, you can arrive 5 minutes early 
and take a 4 1/2 hour train from city centre to city centre, with more 
space to sit and roam, a restaurant area, site seeing, and no restrictions 
on electronics and internet use.

More often than not, the train is used for traveling shorter distances.  I 
took me 15 minutes and $4 to visit Hangzhou or 45 minutes and $10 to visit 
Shanghai this past year.  Driving would take 45 minutes and 2 hours, 
respectively, and cost much more in gas.

The idiot on the video is missing the point, here.  There is a reason that 
hundreds of millions of people use the train system.  I wish we had them in 
North America.﻿

I ride China's high-speed rail all the time.  I really don't mind the 
increased travel time, as it's a MUCH more comfortable experience.  The 
seats are bigger, you don't have grouchy stewardesses barking at you to 
buckle up, turn something off, sit down, shut up, etc.  In fact, sometimes 
it's a shorter trip that way too.  I traveled from Shanghai to Panjin in 9 
hours this March. If I'd have flown, I'd have left my hotel 90 minutes 
earlier than I did, and assuming the flight was on time, I'd have been to 
Shenyang another 3.5 hours later.  Then I'd have to go from the airport (10 
miles or so from the city, so about an hour, and I expect to be ripped off 
for it) to the train station for a 1.5 hour trip by bus, train or taxi. 
 The train was half the price, and all I had to do was sit back and enjoy 
the ride.  

I'd totally do a 2 day trip to the U.S, every time, no question about it. 
 The only thing I hate more than a commercial jetliner is the airport it 
leaves from.﻿

I'm currently in Chengdu, China. been living here for 7 months. And I'll 
tell you that their expertise at building subway systems is very good. I'm 
from Montreal, Canada and it puts ours to shame in terms of security and 
efficiency: There are motorized glass doors and glass walls to prevent 
anyone from falling/jumping on the tracks. In the rush hour, they have 
people exit the wagon on one side, and people enter it on the other. 
 Cellular communication is possible throughout the whole network and 
there's  AC everywhere. Airport style security scan before entering any 
station. etc, etc. It's like this in all large cities of china I've been 
to. AND it's cheap as hell at a maximum of $0,80 per ride.  
      
They are very capable of building a tunnel connecting Asia to America. And 
even if it's not that fast now, that would open the door for future train 
technologies to use it.

   Maglev vacuum trains are just around the corner and the tests show it 
will be triple as fast as commercial jets at a staggering 2900 km/h (about 
1,800 mph.) . This will bring work to all the countries it goes through and 
I think it'll be a good thing to connect the world like this. A train can 
move a lot more people and goods than planes can with much less energy 
(thus less pollution), especially if it's maglev in a vacuum (zero 
friction). And comparing a electric high speed train tunnel to a dam as far 
as impact on environment is laughable fallacy. 

bringing down the cost and carbon footprint of travelling across the ocean 
seems like a good idea to me. Even with current technology, I'd be willing 
to take a two days trip from if it meant my ticket was the price of a local 
flight. 

This is the future.﻿

Well I agree on most parts of this video, but building a railway to the US 
is actually a good idea, kerosene is highly expensive and it's the main 
reasons why buying an airline ticket is so expensive, however a railway 
system to intercontinental areas will highly reduce the cost and increase 
the availability of passengers to get there, plus there won't be any flight 
delays or such. The train from Beijing to Shenzhen only costs 120~ USD . 
Which means a train ticket from Beijing to USA would be around 700 USD, a 
great deal for economic spenders. 
Like I said, the video itself is pretty true and humorous , but building a 
railway from china to the US is not a bad idea.﻿
